text: @RokoMijicUK I think monogamy has a bit more going for it than low effort - like opting out of the constant preoccupation with juggling people and building a family with someone you can reasonably expect will be home for dinner the next day and treat his children like they’re his.

Self-esteem really *is* as important as we’re told, but it’s also impossible to generate by decree. 

The more self-esteem becomes policy, the less it is possible in reality, because it is an inner test that you never get to pass, because you are told you passed it already.

text:
@m8popkin I think they have a point. There’s a lot of suffering tied into weight, and needlessly torturing people isn’t a solution. Neither is lying to them. 

The solution is simple, but hard to implement, and it’s made even harder by the fact that we’re just so good at food marketing.

That doesn’t mean we should point and laugh. But HAES is BS. “Healthy at a Reasonable Range of Sizes that Won’t Kill You in Middle Age” doesn’t have the same ring to it, but is the truth. 
You don’t have to be rail thin, but these ladies are a few weight classes above rubenesque.

text:
The real cost of *building a life*, owning a home, raising children, being able to work close to family, being insured against the vagaries of existence - is through the roof. 

People should prioritize well, but the ever-present whisper of capital isn’t helping.

If the cost of fast food, fast fashion, TVs, streaming and smartphones is lower that doesn’t mean people are on the whole richer. 

It means people have been psyop-ed by marketing into ever more *needs* that consume them just as much as they consume products.

text: Treating different things the same, as any equity-minded progressive will confirm, doesn’t work.

But the world of men is not the world. 

Both men and women lose when their spaces are:

2. eliminated or alternatively subjected to restructuring and integration because separation is oppressive.

text:
"The Moral Basis of a Backward Society" by Edward C Banfield

A study of regional differences in social capital, where Banfield visits a small town in southern Italy to discover that it's a game-theoretic hellscape few can escape from. Great for peeps interested in coordination

"Black Mass" by John Gray

Gray argues that contemporary politics and economics have more in common with millenarian cults and apocalyptic religion than our technocratic betters would lead on. https://t.co/fTFilrvvU4

"Human Smoke" by Nicholson Baker

A vivid historical account of the run-up to and the start of the Second World War presented in vignettes that show how emergent history is from the quirks and misjudgments of individuals. https://t.co/vBjn1KAM6c

"The Machiavellians: Defenders of Freedom" by James Burnham

Probably the best book on political theory I've read, only matched by Burnham's "The Managerial Society" https://t.co/70hJtdXww2

"Sexual Personae" by Camille Paglia. 

*The* *based* book on sexual archetypes of the Western imagination - and not shy of nature, au contraire. https://t.co/hfZHTEfj8e

"Why Liberalism Failed" by @PatrickDeneen 

Yep. What it says on the tin. 

Powerful argument that liberalism is the water we swim in and has the seeds of its own demise baked in. Excellent book, foundational. https://t.co/tECrCpTqO3

"The Elephant in the Brain" by @robinhanson & Kevin Simmler. 

An absolute beast of a perspective-shifting book on signaling - an indispensable lens on reality. https://t.co/59S4MiUxuN

Top books of 2020.

*books I read this year, not that came out this year. That would not be Lindy. 

Inspired by @robkhenderson (though I lack the excellent highlights being tied to my Kindle out here at the outskirts of the empire).
RT @SpencerKlavan: One of my absolute favorite new writers, @kaschuta, makes her debut today at @theammind. This is a searching and perfect…
Next pandemic - a mutant strain of biblical crotch rot. https://t.co/Nlpn864sLx

text: @quachelsey Oooh, that’s probably the worst scenario. Out of the frying pan, into the PATRIARCHY.

Or - that’s the moment you go whole hog on the PATRIARCHY. 

Nothing like a good conspiracy theory to deflate cognitive dissonance.

30 is just another year, it isn’t 20, though. 

It’s its own blessing, if you navigate right.
@apex_pl Hey, but it’s FREE

The idea that life is about cultivating infinite optionality is what is dooming women into freaking out post-30. 

That’s when it begins to dawn on you that your options are limited by nature itself.

The complaints are typically based on a few factors:
- Being a free agent and desk larper is often not as fun as it used to be. 
- Biological clock (a stark reality).
- Cognitive dissonance about the situation and it’s potential inescapability.

I think it’s more about finding your place in life. 

If you’re over 30 and are still playing the “who can make a better spreadsheet and eat at yet another asian fusion place” it does become grim fast. https://t.co/RCqz7mwT8J

text: @Accerleration Extinction from a virus with a 99%+ survival rate is a very bad plot for a disaster movie.

@Soulphood Expanding hospital capacity was one of the first steps taken, but many of these ad-hoc hospitals were never even used. If strengthening the health system was the challenge, confining people to their homes is a far flung solution.
@Rationalbot Yep, *voluntary sacrifice* of one’s own life to the divine is not even an exception to the punishment rule, it’s a voluntary embrace of it.

The idea that to conquer death we must give up life has a dark irony to it. 

More people alive doesn't mean more people living.

Sure, this verdict doesn't seem as dark as long as we have the internet as a social pacifier, but real human contact is not optional. 

Humans aren't ants, but we're also not ethereal, self-contained units. The "others" are not a nice to have, they are what makes life worth it.

The lockdowns are inhuman because they are the epitome of the assumption of individuality. 

What in the past was seen as a punishment for only the most vicious of criminals, solitary confinement, is now seen as just another, equivalent, lifestyle.
@DickFeynman5 You can only be credibly detached if you’re actually funny. A minority of people develop great humor because it’s biologically costly to spend time on frivolous word play.

@sapheneias Hmm, ok. Don’t really see a contradiction, I just said it’s not just one way.

Important to remember when talking about normalization: not only does demand create supply but supply also creates demand. 

Nothing happens in the void, frens.

@jesseclain Again, these are not separate, they are linked. Things are not moral in a vacuum. 

Fin.
@VicJulianTwit @GwendolynKansen Very cool

@jesseclain I think we came full circle, can only point you to my response. 

Destigmatization is the precursor to normalization. This isn’t self-harm, where everyone agrees it’s bad. It’s something promoted as “just as good”.

@jesseclain I don’t think that’s how humans think. Something can’t be “ok” and also “not ok” at the same time. 

It’s a bit of semantic play, destigmatize would necessarily need to mean that it’s “ok”, if the next thing is, “but don’t do it” it won’t really work.

@jesseclain I think that’s a bit of a stretch. Whatever you think about being gay, it’s usually not something you decide on one morning. Polyamory solves for the problem of sexual variety (a universal problem) and sex work solves for money (idem).
@jkd6666 The idea that these are independent is what I don’t buy.
@jesseclain The idea that the two are independent is what I don’t buy. A thing js rare until it’s common, through exactly the process of destigmatization -> normalization.
@GwendolynKansen It’s one of my favorite books
@GwendolynKansen I love “The art of possibility” by Rose & Ben Zander
I don’t believe shaming individual people is a good tactic, but maintaining stigma around life strategies that will probably go sideways for a randomly chosen individual is sane.

The truth is, without pro-social defaults, people often do what is expedient for their immediate goals, which usually means money. 

Things like sex work are the epitome of expediency. Even most vocal proponents will admit that the curve of returns on the job declines with age.

The default option, if it’s worth its social coordinating salt, should encourage family formation and the best environment for raising children, the nucleus of future society itself. 

Norms promote the default and stigma for alternatives protects it.

Ideally, this would lead to a very small minority of *qualified* people experimenting with poly. 

The reality is that people’s powers of self-assessment are famously weak. About half the population would read that description and think: “Hmm, bingo, that’s me!”
Many proponents of polyamory admit that it’s not for everyone. https://t.co/BNrbXLbQII

The fact that for some people, alternative lifestyles are a better fit, and I’m not disputing that this is the case, is not a great argument for normalizing them. 

Things like polyamory or even sex work may be a great fit for a minority of people, but chaos for most.

People depend on norms to guide them through life. 

Humans are mimetic creatures - more often than not, we default to the level of informal norms. 

Norms work, and the have immense coordination value: I can predict what you’ll do and you can predict what I’ll do.
@textstomyfwb They did, just not one pivotal to discovering, managing and mitigating the greatest nuclear disaster on earth. Every other character was real, fyi.

This will not end well.

text:
Just want to say a big thank you to my Twitter frens. 

You’ve made this quasi-dystopian bunker existence much more fun, more entertaining and more educational than I could have ever expected.
@kirtlenus What applies to aliens applies to Hungarians, ask any of my neighbors 😛
@SeanOwe20378473 I think it still goes on mostly undisturbed in more working class and more male circles. Once female norms got established in the workplace, sensitivity needed to be “trained”.
Thank you, Chris! https://t.co/LLdkx3K4DP

It’s a minefield that people living in border towns know to clear by running through it almost immediately, but this wisdom seems lost on the most cosmopolitan of us, in the idea that we should be beyond these things. We aren’t.

Living in the West, it was obvious that, at least in “knowledge worker” circles, walking on eggshells was the norm. 

Had a joke about an “Irish exit” once, and it was received with the deer-in-the-headlights look of someone who knows that “we do not speak of such things.”

Differences were celebrated *because* they were noticed. They were part of the flavor of a friend, both positive and negative. 

In the absence of that, the alternative was often sullen, simmering conflict that would break out in bar fights or the occasional knife incident.

This is a stark statement, but I think it’s correct. 

Having grown up at the intersection of different ethnic and religious groups (a german ethnic in a romanian/hungarian border town) the first sign of friendship was “ethnic roughhousing”. https://t.co/dd9yxaVRxo
@VanceCrowe Uh oh 😂
@VanceCrowe You need a bigger freezer 😬

text:
Mediocrity is always a good giveaway for ideology. 

Whatever journalism, piece of visual art or even service you look at, if it’s shitty, there’s a good chance it wasn’t properly scrutinized because it fit a certain dominant ideology, so it was more costly to edit than just nod.
@AndySwan Colleges

Had a bad feeling, and now Derek is gone. 

Went by the owl tree to see if any were still there. 

Now there were *9*. The omens keep piling on.

There’s also the parameter of beauty. 

Beauty often clusters around money, as the Matthew principle dictates. The lower classes often lack both, or at least the means of beautification available to the well off. The lot lizard is not a lot butterfly for nothing.

Weaponizing social justice language to cover for moral grey  (or black) areas?

Unheard of. https://t.co/qAZvx40M1n
@PresentWitness_ That's just you being "irrational".
@jb_61820 I think this happened in Germany already - @auboutducoeur posted about it
@jb_61820 Exactly, if sex work is (just) work, then why not contribute to the collective, my dear?

Normalizing "sex work" needs to take this into consideration. Destigmatization of glamour shots has little to do with the serious plight of people engaged in work much more degrading and dangerous by its very nature. These are not the same.

Few of the people so proletarian to engage in the low impact, one-way street of posting nudes for money, could even fathom what it takes, in sheer steel stomach points and, very often, in desperation, to need to do the latter.

"Sex work" is a term to make bourgeois middle & upper-middle-class ladies feel better about selling upskirt shots. 

Between that and sleeping with 15 truckers a night there is a chasm greater than human language can encompass.
@ACryptberg @wu_vienna @VanceCrowe Ha, it’s not a dire curriculum, just mislabeled 😂
@savszymura Oh, he does.
@Duderichy Learning languages as a child is different from “language nerd” fetishism. It’s genuinely easier and definitely mind expanding to be able to think in multiple languages early on.
@RokoMijicUK @default_friend Sounds like it opens up the "social credit score" pandora's box.

text:
How long can you consent to not consent for money? 

A lot of sex positive libertarian-types seem to think that this problem is solved if we just gave prostitutes the same social status as accountants and other service providers. But deep down, we know it's no haircut or manicure

The final question, to me, lies in how we view sex work. Is it just a job like any other? 

I, personally, struggle with this - many jobs have terrible health outcomes and are ruinous to the body, even deadly (logging come to mind), but this one seems to cause soul erosion. https://t.co/0DkJ2qDo2Y
Add the state as "guarantor" of said human right and, of course, the taxpayer as the eternal underwriter. https://t.co/DZb72S1Awb

text:
What would happen if Twitter let you monetize your profile? 

I'm pretty much for it, but I think it would create some much more hardcore incentives for virality (and negative virality). Long effortpoast threads would be slowly replaced by more refined ragebait.

@billybobmcmanus I think this is exactly true - not only dangerous, but highly ineffective. Appealing to empathy and building SJW-style rights movements as representatives of disenfranchised men is a hard trick to pull off, because empathy is in short supply. It's a raw deal, but the reality.
@jolly_raptor @joshua_spring1 Been decorating all weekend, so this is a good assessment.
@thane_black Ah, this is lovely to hear 🙏 welcome to a world of weird labels!

@The_Richard_J Hmmm. 

Depends on:
1. The delta between your model and base reality (I believe it is huge).
2. The consequences of your decisions if the model is wrong. 
Decisions also don't start from 0, every iteration loads up on path dependencies & lock-in effects, etc.
@billybobmcmanus Fair point, and I agree that MRAs have some stellar arguments behind them, but not every discrepancy is unfair. Or at least, it is unfair at a fundamental level, not a social one.
@falsesong 😂
@LaureMartel I think they're both localists/decentralization fans, a lot of overlap in that respect.
@ramshackerino Yep
@Eco_Nat_V2 It's not ideal, but "perspectives" is too snooty for something which is delivered in tweet form.

I'm pretty much a fallen rationalist, and I think many of my compadres are making a similar pilgrimage. A little bit about rally point "trad".  

*Do subscribe to my substack if you want to contribute to female empowerment and support the second world. 

https://t.co/ExbZkwUaZw
@der_iidiot 😂

@doxometrist @CoriKimJo Like your link hints at, yes, the world is naturally more callous towards the plight of men. I think you can wave your fist at society for that or understand that it's something you have to work with.

@doxometrist @CoriKimJo I think they're fighting an uphill battle and can't afford to be waving around false equivalencies because it weakens their case. Divorce laws, paternity, abortion rights, etc. lots of things to work on and raise awareness for.

@dual_profile I think distinguishing rape from other forms of predatory behavior is important. Women are abusers and predators as well, but rape is a very specific act that just adds a layer of cringe that repells people from the important points MRAs have to bring.
@HyperDupont Post-rape trauma bond, I guarantee it.
@HyperDupont There’s plenty of predatory things women do that are just as bad, but these false equivalencies aren’t it, chief.

@HyperDupont I think it’s reprehensible and deranged, but it’s just a different type of act. Lumping it together with rape for the sake of equality isn’t serving anyone, because people instinctively know it’s not the same thing. I feel it discredits MRAs who have very good points otherwise.

@Songbir95377759 I think that’s a part of it, sure. But the idea that the world should and will eventually be equal between a gender with almost all the reproductive power and one with almost none is ludicrous and SJW tier. Obviously this is not all of MRA, buy heard the “women rape” too often.

@CoriKimJo Not at all, just that the “see, you’re being a hypocrite” doesn’t really work for them. A lot of both feminism and MRA is essentially waving your fist at nature and calling it “society”. 

They’d be better served if they understood this.

Do things, physical things, in quiet places with wide and distant horizons. 

Get tired, get cold, get silent.

Sleep it off.

@RaccoonYeshua Masculinity is that which asserts itself - women, fortunately or unfortunately, don’t have to play this role.

@RaccoonYeshua I don’t think this is “as it should be” or even “as has been”, but the tension seems more acute in our gender egalitarian world. 

Female lust is much more conditional than male *drive*, and egalitarian households (with all their advantages) create this tension.

@Gerontion4 Could be, but not sure what came first. BC is a huge civilizational disruption, but T levels are dropping precipitously within living generations. This isn’t sexual selection, it’s something even more insidious.

@titusfilm This is the definition of semantics. Your assertion is that everything is nature, I guess, so nothing can be outside of nature. You are using a different definition than me, and trying to take down an argument I didn't make.

5/This is a hard▪️to ⭕️

Whatever path you choose, being human means accepting these contradictions, seeing the tradeoffs, playing out the scenarios and knowing: there is no heaven to get to, just making your own blend of peace in the permanent war of nature.

4/The predator/prey relationship that is so *obviously* at the core of much of female arousal is disrupted by the simple fact that your partner, if he’s a good one, is hardly a very convincing predator.

3/It’s a collision of order and chaos, with the expectation that it’s easy to balance, and if it isn’t, well, it wasn’t meant to be. 

But chaos constrained isn’t chaos at all. It’s role-play. It’s 50 Shades of Grey, it’s slaps and chokes and artificial add-ons.

2/The Apollonian order of marriage is an attempt at relief from the mind-numbing Dionysian abyss of sexuality. 

The idea that a marriage not only can, but needs to maximize sexual fulfillment for both parties is very new and contains a contradiction.

text:
5/ Currently, we have no ideas what to do with young female sexuality, because the idea that there is even something *to do* is anathema to liberalism. 

But that doesn't make nature shrug and go away.

4/ The traps are many. 

From the presence of an inevitable percentage of predators, commercialized sexuality as a progressive "positive", or simply facing the world-warping moral hazard of being given the keys to the kingdom at puberty, this is a hard problem.

3/ In the past, we had fairly totalitarian and, yes, hamfisted mechanisms to protect both women and society from this cosmic event, but they were there for a reason. 

Now, liberated from the constraints of tradition, these girls and society collide unprepared for each other.

2/ It's immense power, paired with immense danger, all arriving almost overnight. 

While most guys are devising complex strategies on how to convince these girls to give up the goods, the task of managing the "goods" is proportionately complex, both psychologically & morally.

1/ One thing most men won't be able to understand is how overwhelming the transformation is from awkward pre-teen to being a young, pretty female. 

It's like being gifted a fortune at 15, but it's boobie trapped and the instructions are written by a Cosmo intern who hates dad.

Bursting the university bubble should be a civilizational priority. 

It’s debt slavery for a more and more meaningless document. 

The fact that it’s now a “hygiene factor” means it’s not even a decent IQ/conscientiousness test anymore.
The death of the family is just one more necessary step to redemption.

One strain of discourse doesn’t hide this fact:

*Western society is sinful at its core, deserves to end and good riddance to it. More noble people deserve to inhabit this land.* https://t.co/YmWMFItS0c

text: @JustAFactsMan I guess that’s the luxury component ☺️
@erikbryn You’re rich enough to live insulated from the lives and help of others, which was almost never the case historically.
@rhizostigmata Completely agree, one of my main issues with libertarianism.
Not knowing your neighbors is first luxury, then curse.

Self-selected loneliness is epidemic. 

I believe it’s about as dangerous to our souls as sugar is to our bodies.

It’s fun in the short term, but in the long term, something important starts to waste away. 

Your capacity to negotiate the social world, to simply *be together* atrophies.

Individualism is a revealed preference. 

People, overall, prefer to be left alone (now that they don’t depend on others for survival) and it shows in their choices. 

But most people also prefer gorging themselves on sugar and not rolling off the couch.
@fly_r2 It’s the female equivalent of sending dick pics. Women think that because they care, men care. They don’t.

text: Also, and this is a huge point, most people are not only unprepared to look at conservative arguments, they come pre-loaded with a lifetime of platitudes and demonization that seems to reduce their functional cognition by at least 50 IQ points.

It’s not that enjoyable, and it’s also treacherous, as conservative thought often comes pre-loaded with prejudice. 

So, the task becomes explaining why you should not only come to the minefield, but cross it, because there are riches on the other side.

It’s not that I don’t try to engage with people around me, it would be a joy to be able to. 

The conversation just seems to get bogged down in me having to explain my priors for a long time until we can even reach the starting gate.

I think it depends on what your interested in. 

As a conservative woman with all sorts of non-mainstream interests, the magical betweenness of deep conversations is in short supply irl. 

I have other conversations, of course, but nothing as stimulating as Twitter. https://t.co/FXKIqIg6sn

text:
9. Catering to an audience.

It's clear to me that my audience likes my takes on feminism & dating, and are so-so/meh on my political philosophy musings. I part voluntarily, part involuntarily take this into account, especially if it's a "slow week." 

I've come to expect my fix.

Since I started using Twitter, though, I got more writing gigs than I can reasonably handle for some excellent publications that I wouldn't have dreamed of writing for, even this August. 

In terms of writing opportunities, Twitter has been the best "investment" I've ever made.

text: @TheRaisinGirl I’m sorry 😐

That’s why I’m not that keen on the “Whodunnit” stream of anti-woke thought. 

Cultural patterns are emergent from historical, technological and, in the end, material conditions. 

It’s never simply a cabal of baddies.

Unpopular opinion: we’d be pretty much in the same place culturally if someone rounded up the members of the Frankfurt School and all the pomo Frenchies and bombed them before they had time to philosophize.

2/ The problem is, if the market is flooded with exhibitionist sexuality as currency, inflation happens. 

Your WAP is debased in more ways than one, ladies.

1/ Female empowerment seems to mean total sexual self-objectification, but under a strict look-but-don’t-touch rule for men. 

It’s harnessing sexuality for all of its power, and wielding it like a hammer.
I guess manther could be the counterpart to gold digger. But we already have the much more evocative “cradle-snatcher.”
@17cShyteposter Hey, but arbeit macht frei.

And the prize for most unnecessary neologism goes to “manther.”

In Eastern Europe, they’re called “men.” https://t.co/7bjLXdylCJ

They’re waiting to find “the perfect specimen” that has all the aspects they liked from tens, hundreds of other women. 

She doesn’t exist, so they keep churning.

My observation is that the small minority of men who can get the polygynous harem enjoy it for a while, and then get tired of it. 

The problem is that most are so warped by choice by then that they can’t get off the carousel. https://t.co/KZQHczJNOQ

@ElonBachman Hmmm. Not sure father = babysitter. I think it’s definitely a help, but “disrupting single parenthood” may be a stretch. 

Shared genes matter.

Letting an algorithm run this facet of our lives optimizes for proximal individual preferences. 

Sounds good on the surface, but, unsurprisingly for humans, it turns everything into a highly unequal, informally polygynous harem for the top 5-10% of men.

This is a monumental graph.

I noticed that about 4-5 years ago, the norm shifted from “talking to people” to swiping for people. 

This is a birth control-sized revolution in mating and it’s already reshaped our societies. https://t.co/OsdRgGfv86

@TomUmarHunter Sure, but who's doing the shaming? People they trust and respect and understand? 

No. It's just some "misogynists on the internet". It's not society and it doesn't scale, it just limits the influence of the ideas of the right.

I'm not against shaming, I think it's an indispensable social coordination mechanism. 

But it really doesn't work if the only people power-shaming you are also the only people who could coherently explain why you're in the mess you're in. https://t.co/fpyaXIlKub

Women know there is a problem, they just have no coherent theory, because there is none in the mainstream. 

And it seems like the people who do have a theory don't want to share it beyond "boo, you whore"

I really care about promoting these ideas, and have learned a lot from this corner of hidden intellectual gems. 

But these aren't social taboos anymore that people are breaking - they are the result of a 24/7 barrage of encouragement from all angles of the liberal establishment.

I really think the dissident right has good ideas about the relationship between men and women and making it sustainable and positive, ideas that you don't hear anywhere else (except for maybe fading religious communities and even there, the framing is dogmatic and stale).

The problem is casual sex and "sexual liberation" aren't social taboos anymore. They are very mainstream. 

If the only shaming mechanism left is a sea of anons calling you a whore, the result isn't "whoah, let me rethink my life choices". https://t.co/PEp0jOCGQ4

I’m sympathetic to both perspectives and I think life experience can push someone down one or the other. 

In time, though, the idea of externalities has become more and more important to me as I think beyond myself and my immediate gratification.

2 takes the idea of post-rational more seriously and brings in the idea of second-order consequences. 

So, though you can do experiments in living, this view maintains that you are probably partly blind to the consequences for *yourself* and almost wholly blind to systemic ones.

1, the “experiments” faction requires a deeper commitment to rationalism proper, the idea that you can try lifestyles on, see what fits, and you will *know* what works for you. 

The perspective here is individual, solipsistic. This is your journey, as a sovereign individual.

I’ve been in both camps, and am now clearly more of an exponent of 2. 

There are a few big assumptions or leaps of faith that distinguish the two factions, but I believe the major one is the adherence to and interpretation of “post-rational”.

It looks like the new-atheist -> rationalist -> post-rationalist space split into two distinct factions. 

1. The “anything goes, let’s see what happens” experiments-in-living faction. 

2. The Chesterton’s Fence, paleocon, RETVRN faction.

@Indian_Bronson People are mythical beings, so I think this is a question of ideology. Religious communities will continue to do fine, and people with deep low time preference commitments will as well. But, yes, unless there's some spiritual revival, the general population is screwed.
@Indian_Bronson That's fine, of course, but I also think that for many men, working toward having a family, despite the risks I do acknowledge, is in their own self-interest.

My point is that, yes, I agree with your assessment of the global dynamics, and I understand that many men want to opt out. But people can only wake up individually, and these are the people I'm addressing.

If women are the authors of their own doom then through the same lens of agency, it seems men have been neutered through not a small amount of complacency. 

Women, even in insane 2020, respect male power and disrespect its absence.

I understand that men are drawing the short straw now, and have been for decades. But the idea that gaining competence and strengthening your masculinity are not useful until some mythical union of women decrees the end of the sexual revolution is also just nihilism.

The ingredients we need are:

text: @Senconac Every young generation is revolutionary. The fact that they managed to funnel this energy straight into the Fortune 500’s pockets is serious innovation.
@bgutting Convincing to your average person, though. The biggest consumer demographic is also the biggest protester demographic - young women.
The greatest trick the global elite ever pulled is to make their interests   “revolutionary” leaving yours to be “reactionary”.
@micahglasser @BeanAbacus well put
@makingamanofme It’s a heuristic. I think there’s good reason for it.
@PereGrimmer Seems like the same example, worded differently around proximity rather than control. But yes, I think the point stands.

@PereGrimmer Under informal norms, there is no need for state intervention. 

Without informal norms, the state comes to solve the problem (badly and with myriad externalities).

@PereGrimmer I'll give you an example: 

(Old) Informal Norm: Patriarchal "control" of young girls' sexuality. 
Problem: Potential paedophilia. 
Law: Surveillance of all communications for traces of sexual exchanges between children and adults.

@PereGrimmer The main norm that is recognized and enforced by the state is tolerance. 

More traditional, pro-social norms are not recognized, because the small communities that enforced them have died out. I think that's a huge problem, we're just seeing the  outline of.

@PereGrimmer I'm talking about preferences, not surveys. Yes, that is their preference both informally and formally, and they will advocate for it, as would anyone else. 

Informal norms are decaying everywhere -> puts pressure on people to advocate in the arena that now matters - the state.

@PereGrimmer People from communities with restrictive norms favor harsh laws when asked about their preference for the laws of an encompassing state. Of course they will, it is obviously their preference locally.

@PereGrimmer The night watchman state, which I agree is preferable, can only exist in a place where the minutiae of life is governed by informal norms. 

In the absence of informal norms, the state balloons to compensate.

@PereGrimmer The issue that I'm highlighting is that we're in a situation that for complex reasons has led to the abolishing of informal norms (separate from the state). 

Norms have to exist, either informal or by decree, to coordinate society.

@flummery5 I think there's truth to that. There's also a fatherly guidance dimension to it, especially with an older, non-competing male. 

There's always a second layer to any relationship, but I think the motherly dimension, especially in therapy, has grown a bit monstrous.

@PereGrimmer Maybe 'legitimacy' is a better word. Does the state map onto informal norms? If yes, it has legitimacy. I would argue a decentralized state typically does this better than a centralized one.

@PereGrimmer I think the more decentralized, the closer local norms can map onto the state. In a centralized state, because the law needs to map to many different demographics, local norms need to take a back seat.
@daily_barbarian Exactly. The more unchained we are from our normal and evolved group coordination mechanisms, the more need we'll have for the state to come in and do it for us.

@PereGrimmer Informal norms are usually culture-specific and local. They're enforced by reputation and oversight. We don't live in that world anymore. The fact that this doesn't scale and the state does, I think accounts for a lot of it.
The fewer informal norms we have, the more laws we need.

As I said before, societal norms need to act as the *healthy default* for your average person. 

If society decides norms are shameful on the whole, because shame is the devil's emotion, it's not empowering people, it's leaving them in the middle of a minefield.

'Virtue nuking' - Normalizing and scaling up supernormal shortcuts to the fulfillment of our most base desires, with no regard for second-order consequences, either for the individual or society. 

See: 
AshleyMadison
SeekingArrangement
And yes, my personal fave, OF

@Jerem_Heinrichs I think many marriages do, but I think it's even more salient if you're trying to work on deep issues with a "specialist," being vulnerable, and then attacked. 

But yes, I think it's a huge issue.

text: @PereGrimmer For example, a small community in Romania, that has 5% high potential population that is free to travel anywhere to benefit from increased wages. They could stay home and build equity here, but they are free to choose so most leave. How would the community be represented here?
@PereGrimmer Ok, how do community preferences get accounted for under libertarianism? Unions?
@PereGrimmer @RaccoonYeshua Ok, but divinity of the individual isn’t the basis for classical liberalism in contrast to libertarianism. The orientation around the individual is the same.

@PereGrimmer So, aggregated individual preferences = community preferences? 

There is a difference.
@RaccoonYeshua @PereGrimmer I think this is the difference between libertarianism and Christianity. I’d be surprised if there was a lot of talk of divinty as a reasoning for classical liberalism.

@PereGrimmer Adam Smith had a great theory for the conditions he was living in about how to optimize production and trade. I agree with him, but what he didn’t foresee is that scaling that up globally would mean the death of the substrate that allows for that trade.

@PereGrimmer It deals with ‘legal entities’, but it doesn’t account for the informal substructure of society - family, community, it can’t optimize for that. It can optimize for growth, which is said ever-more-sophisticated paperclip maximizer.
@forbca @PereGrimmer Market failure to account for the collective and emergent clusters of externalities that individual players can’t predict. It wasn’t Ron Paul, but it is downstream from markets.
@RaccoonYeshua @PereGrimmer What is the difference?
@PereGrimmer For example - was it good for me to emigrate to the west and increase my income & GDP there? Yes for me, a disaster for my collective.
@PereGrimmer The market doesn’t deal with collective interests that often conflict with individual interests.

@PereGrimmer Classical liberalism - libertarianism - needs to deal with the individual, who has individual desires. He is the subject of the market, a producer (moves for work, leaves at 18 to go into debt slavery to be a better producer) and consumer (who exercises choice in everything)

@PereGrimmer My issue with it is that the libertarian strain of liberalism has liberated individuals from those very communities. It’s fine to say that libertarianism just embeds community norms, but what if it abolishes communities in the first place?

@PereGrimmer Choice is important, but it has to have a balancing external framework that has collective goals embedded. This doesn’t mean central planning, but it does mean embedding pro-social goals in regulation.

It was a matter of months between the norm shifting completely from "talk to girl at party" to "start swiping at 2AM at party without chatting up anyone". 

This is the new normal.

@atazimonte I think that’s a different archetype, happens as well. Everyone with decent mate value is incentivized to endlessly shop around.

This is exactly what can be predicted to happen if the price of sex drops to 0. 

Friends with lots of free benefits, because there’s always another friend around the corner.
It sometimes does turn into a relationship, but the power and respect difference dooms it from the start.
It’s perpetual heartache and doubly gut-wrenching because you agreed to it, because you’re so enlightened and worldly and independent.

One of the most common types of relationship in big cities is:

Friends with benefits (where the woman pretends to be ok with it in the hopes it turns into a relationship 🤞🏻)

You can judge people, as everyone does but isn't allowed to admit anymore, and not hate them. 

Judgment is a healthy way in which a collective maintains a normative order. It is only anathema under *normative lawlessness*. 

Think of where that puts our culture.

One of the biggest sleights of hand in our culture was how we've been conditioned to equate judgment with hate. 

I've been called hateful because I believe & say that certain ways of living are more beneficial in the long term for the individual and the community.

@extranslocated Sure. 

I just see the sentiment. People are more scared than ever by the woke hydra. I don’t think your assumptions are correct, but we’ll have to see.

@IGalalien Exact.

Feminism is simply the only culturally sanctioned outlet for female pain.

Female pain is real, it’s increasing, but without a meta narrative based in reality, both it and feminism will continue to grow monstrous.

text: @lovelivenofear Very Nietzschian. He foresaw this quite well and warned about it.
@Alloftheponiees Exactly. It's a game-theoretical balance that is kept in check by strategic shame. It's not optimal for particular individuals, but for society, it may be beneficial overall.
@Rongwrong_ Yes, that was the Burke vs. Mill wrestle. Mill apparently won the culture war.

@atlasontilt The individual, in many ways, cannot see as far as the myths that make up a sustainable society. 

Also, working hard, abstaining from fun stuff, and having lots of kids are a hassle.

@atlasontilt Not the end of the species, the end of the culture that holds these beliefs. 

The problem is that optimizing for the individual is time-blind. You have to optimize for relatively short term benefit. Optimizing for society is often shitty in the short term but has LT benefits

@Alloftheponiees These memes are essentially tied to their stigma. The stigma is the meme.

I'm not saying the non-monogamous are doing the meme killing, the normalization and the very big ask of "non-judgementalism" is the meme killer.

6/ So, I agree that some arrangements are better for some. But killing the memes that are best for most is terrible for everyone. 

* if you're not antinatalist and aren't happy to snuff out our civilization in a few very fun cycles around the sun.

5/ The problem with that is that most people cannot take it. 

They *are* better off sticking to the program. 

And ridding our societies of moral taboos that the "enlightened don't need" will hurt these, the less enlightened, most, as it has already.

4/ If a society allows for the complete destigmatization of taboos around pro-social activities or defection from these,   it's not going to be long for this world. 

You may say, ok, this is only for the enlightened among us, the ones "that can take it" because they are rational

text:
3/ It makes sense for myths to exists that encourage the type of behavior that supports the next generation, thereby propagating both the genes and the memes. 

The "choose your own adventure" meme isn't this type of self-propagating myth. It's self-terminating.

2/ The problem is at the collective level. 

If our collective myths optimize for "shame reduction for each individual", even if this is a noble goal, it's not what myths are for. 

Myths, if they and the population they serve is to survive, need to embed pro-social mores.

The main point of resistance I see against traditional (sexual & other) morality is that people are different and that some more custom arrangements fit some particular people better. 

I don't disagree that this could be the case for some.

text: I think there is a good amount of evidence to believe that stable, two-parent families between reliable people with low time preference are a safe place to raise children, which is something conservatives intuit.

text: Romanians call a manta ray a “sea cat” but it ain’t no business goose. https://t.co/hY0Doa7xBh

@chrisjwmartin There’s a horse/cart problem here, because a lot of economists look to revealed preference as a guiding light. 

Increasing appeal through prior commitments usually comes once you already know your preference is destructive.
@chrisjwmartin But most things in the market are becoming *more* like drugs, rather than less so. We can’t outlaw everything, but we can understand than our desires aren’t a guide to life.
@BeigeShiba Villains are always permutations on ‘dad’.

@chrisjwmartin The more down the path of supernormal stimuli we go, the closer we become to this scenario. 

We’re chained to our desires in a self-loathing cycle, never being able to quit, because it’s too good.

@chrisjwmartin It’s a true reflection of *desire*, but in many ways, stated preferences are truer. 

It’s like the desire of a drug addict - his revealed preference is shooting up, his stated preference is quitting.
@yama_pain It’s an individual struggle.

@yama_pain Uh oh. 

Well that puts any discussion of politics beyond stark nihilism outside the discussion.
@2xminus1 This is too cerebral for even my highly intellectual followers

@yama_pain That’s one leash. All of civilization has been one form or another of leash.

I’m not arguing that we should abolish the market, I’m arguing that it’s in our best interest to assign it its proper place, as a tool, not a God.

@yama_pain We’ve perfected and escalated the fulfillment of desire to the point that  it could singlehandedly destroy us. 
And yes, it needs a leash. Can we construct one? Probably not.

@yama_pain I think desire is revealed preference. It doesn’t stem from individual wills, it’s as old as time. 

My issue is that libertarian economists use desire fulfillment as a sufficient measure for the state of the world.
@yama_pain Yes, and desire is endless. Without a framework to understand that, this is a self-terminating process.
@laCamelote 😂

Humans need an external scaffold, a structure, a light. 

Worshipping choice is fatal, because choice is not free.

What a marketer is able to sell your monkey brain is not a guide to life. 

You'll buy anything that scratches the howling itch that evolution planted in there.
@exnl0 Semantics.

text:
9/  You get what you optimize for, and if this is the prime optimization function - individual utility - the result is 2020. 

This leaves out considerations of the collective, which used to be a guiding light, but are now anathema because they fail the test of universalism.

8/ Liberalism, in both its classical and progressive variants, is essentially a prioritization of "optimizing for the individual". 

Conservatives optimize for the producer/consumer. 

Liberals optimize for the experiencer/body.

7/ Conservatives are always just a few years behind any new progressive trend. 

This is no vision, so they lose on culture every time. 

Nobody likes the guy showing up 10 minutes late, cap in hand, mumbling objections, but getting with the program.

6/ The right, in its conservative dimension, has no ideological leg to stand on in liberal "water". 

Religiosity was somewhat of an anchor, but now, most conservatives are just liberals who have an inkling about the precautionary principle and a '50s aesthetic.

5/ The left represents progressive liberalism, where the individual is free from the "arbitrary" constraints of society, like sexual mores and various taboos.

Freedom here consists of freedom *to* access sustenance, healthcare, education, jobs, and, currently, also public esteem

4/ Both the left and right are liberal, in the sense that they are committed to liberating the individual.

The right represents 'classical liberalism'/libertarianism, where the idea is that the individual needs to be free to pursue prosperity through the market - freedom *from*

3/ is the answer to our problems, and if we could just rid the world of illiberalism, which seems to be an endless and accelerating whack-a-mole game, we'd be golden. 

The problem is that Liberalism is water.

It's been the guiding framework for so long that we can't see it.

@misha_saul I wonder if “picking on the weak one” wasn’t just a strategy to shield themselves from the smart kids. 

They were in on it, so they were protected from the more effective cruelty of the smart kids, that could really bring them down.

I had great teachers that I loved, kind, wonderful people, and can’t say I hate anyone. 

But I sure can think of a lot of people who have good reasons to be traumatized by the same teachers.

The truth is, there wasn’t much the teachers could do, because the material got progressively very hard. But it was almost like they picked on the weaker kids to impress the smart ones. 

The throwaway cruelty was the worst.

This was pretty common practice in  Romania back in the day, dumb-shaming. 

There was also no recourse for these kids, their parents often just needed to pay for “after school tutoring” from the same teachers who would just end up teaching them the quiz stuff.

Reminds me of a teacher of mine, who was casually cruel to the slower kids, on the principle that “they were just not trying hard enough.”

She was great if you were smart, but I never respected her after I saw her petty authoritarianism. https://t.co/Db28nOpi8p

The fact that the law says that this is the cut-off point for "legality" doesn't mean that these girls have any clue what they are doing. 

Being callous about young girls "knowing what they're getting themselves into" is not great for the fabric of the society we all live in.

Is it fair to say that the person in this experiment is not equipped to make these decisions? 

Is it fair to say that an 18-year-old millionaire may be easy prey for people who are good at exploiting people in that position?

Let's play this as a thought experiment. 

Think about having all the money you'll ever have as an 18-year-old and no instruction whatsoever on how to spend it wisely (because imparting this knowledge is deemed sexist/patriarchal). https://t.co/rMTwVYgzxI
@antihero_kate Yep, someone DMd me the same info. It’s really disturbing.
@AndrewNWest 👀

text: @smoothboney Also, natural selection is very obviously the overarching explanation, signaling theory offers a proximal explanation for more granular phenomena.

@smoothboney I don’t think you can have that conclusion from anything I’ve said: “hollow of any other meaning”. The idea is simply that stated motivations aren’t always trustworthy and that we are blind to many of these motivations.
@smoothboney What’s an alternative theory of humor?
@JulHenderson99 I think we can have a better theory of what drives us, but it’s not clear that it works as self-help. I

@JulHenderson99 I think it’s wise to be aware of this and understand that below the small window of rational thought there is an immensity of evolutionarily optimized machinery humming away in a black box.

@JulHenderson99 “Real”, “shallow”, “authentic” these are labels that we attach.

Your motivations are ultimately mysterious to you, you speak, you act and there is a mix of biological impulse and social optimization in everything.

I think the crux here is that one can be a true believer and be signaling at the same time. 

The blackpill is the unconsciousness of the process (even more so in oneself) https://t.co/4yjEAu9RZh
@aephax @robinhanson Hanson is a bona fide pill dispenser of various sorts. Really love his work.
13/ @robinhanson has done the most and most interesting work in popularizing this field and I highly recommend his book “The Elephant in the Brain” for more insights into signaling theory.

12/ It’s a blackpill because we remain largely unconscious about our real motivations.

And though the darker motivations of our enemies seem obvious, they and their acolytes are by definition blind to them, and vice versa.

11/ To get the signaling frame do a thought experiment. Imagine yourself as an alien on this planet trying to understand our species.

The things you find weird about our behavior can usually be better explained by signaling than by most other human rationalizations.
